comment: Almost mysterious.   Peat smoke predominant but fruitiness wafts in and out.  There one moment and then gone.    Nose, palate and finish all excellent. About as good as scotch gets.

Last time I drank this it was almost perfect but this time it seems to have a stronger alcohol taste taking away from the usual smooth burnt honey flavour. Smells nicer when the glass is empty. Will try it again.

Exceptional. Smooth yet peaty. Approachable but earthy and salty. Wife doesn’t want to be near me when I drink it. Perfect. All jokes aside I think this is the best Islay scotch you can buy for the money. Drank it by the bonfire and had an aged Padron 3000 to go with it. Did not want this dram or the Padron to end!
Wonderful balance between smoke and body
Peat smoke, brine, floral, late sweetness

Nose: 4,25* Sweet, subtle peat layered underneath, salty grilled fish, citric 
orange

Palate: 4* Lighter, oak spices, dark chocolate, cigar smoke, serrano ham

Finish: 4,5* Long lasting, spicy wood, ashy, bonfire smoke, honey marinade

Elegantly smoked, though not sophisticated. Funky but in the best way possible.
Full bodied with a great balance. Finish lasts forever. Fantastic value.
Briny, cigar smoke, seaweed, well balanced.
Smoke, peat, brine. Hints of floral sweetness. Oily, medium body.

Nose: peaty, iodine, sweetness, seashore smells
Taste: smoke, peat, and again the general sweetness, some laurel
Finish: warm glow, somewhat bitter
Smoked meat! Like a helping of brisket on a smoked tobacco leaf. Not very medicinal, lightly sweet, medium+ bodied
Tastes like waking up after a night at a train station...

Nose: Intense peat smoke with iodine. Stone and tropical fruit, sherry, vanilla and Lapsang Souchong tea. Bandaids.

Flavor: Rich, sweet, complex, smooth. Smoke, iodine, peat. Brine, pineapple, vanilla, orange zest, cherry, rubber, barley-malt. back of the throat is buttery, salt, pepper, and smoke. Finishes long, warm and peppery but still sweet. Balanced. 

Water cools the heat and brings out Indian curry notes. A stone brings out molasses, vanilla, sweetness. Both slightly dull complexity.  Prefer this one neat.

The finest whisky(or any spirit) I’ve ever tasted and not sure it’s really close. 4.75/5 to leave room for a surprise contender but I doubt that’s happening.
Explosion of flavors.  Smoke, peat, envelope glue, smooth.  Smoke lingers in your mouth.
strong medicinal smoke and brine, strong oak and tobacco, the smoke lingers long after the finish
The first good peaty smoke scotch I ever drank. Hotel lobby with my homie Nan, Ruler of Pullman Weifang. “Ask your boss we smoke if we wanna.”

This is quite simply one of the best single malts out there. The nose is smoky, but there’s not an overpowering saltiness like with Ardbeg and Laphroaig (both of which are among my favorite scotches as well.) Peat continues onto first taste, but it’s remarkably balanced and smooth down to the finish. It’s more expensive than its Islay counterparts, but it’s worth the additional price.
Nose leather, smoke , brown sugar. Pallet char, leather, smoke, pear
Incredibly smooth, leaves you with a whisper of peat at the end of the tasting, one of my favorites

Nose: peat, sweet incense, sea shore, campfire, orange peel
Palette: rich, warm campfire smoke, wood tannins, orange peel, brine
Finish: wood tannins, black pepper, peat smoke
Complex campfire in your mouth. Beautiful.

Huge fan of peaty whiskeys but think lagavulin 16 is a bit overrated. Solid drink all around but lacks the X factor for me. Personally prefer Ardbeg or Laphroaig when I am in the mood for a peaty drink.

not a particular fan of islay heavy peated whiskies but i have to admit that lagavulin 16 although its meaty ashy peaty character has some sweetness in it and is actually pretty drinkable for my standards with a long lasting finish

Nose: peat, incense, brine, sea shore, berries, orange peel, floral note
Palette: brine, peat, incense, meatiness, sweet ?? Note. 
Finish: long, rich, incense, brine, sweet floral note
An excellent example of an Islay. Complex and well balanced with all of the key elements one would expect from this region.
Peaty and smoky. Really smooth. I usually like Islays, but something about the grassy taste throws me off.
Smoky, peaty, salty taste of heaven.
Tasty smooth yet smokey Isley whisky one of my favourite
Super. Prijzige fles, aanbieding Wilde Whisky Weken heel tijd terug

Reading reviews I thought this was going to be a peat bomb. Maybe I've had so many peated drams that my palate has adjusted to them. The big flavor I get is BBQ brisket. It's meaty in flavor AND in body. As you taste, you get that deeeeep smoke and meat, but then it lifts off you and get vanilla and those lighter scotch flavors. Which totally blew my mind. I was not expecting it but I love it because it's so smooth. Complex, exciting, and delicious. Highly recommend.
Definitely Peaty.  For a 16 year it tastes much younger.  Needs some water to open up.

I've had a bottle of this before, but never reviewed it, and anyways, it's been a few years since I've tried it. I got my brother-in-law hooked on whisky, and this was what he offered on a recent visit. Thought I'd share a few notes after several years (and several drams in between) this classic pour.

Despite past whinging about low ABV, I'm somehow not bothered by the 43% here. There's still plenty of dense, meaty peat to be found in this dram. Over the years I've gradually tried other offerings from Lagavulin, but to my taste at least, nothing is able to stand up to the standard 16. This spirit just really does well with time in the barrel. The 8 and 9 year old offerings of the past few years have been good, but that extra 7-8 years in the barrel give this dram a depth of flavor and a profile that is so very unique, even amongst Islay pours. In addition to the rich, meaty peat, there's a deep, almost overly tannic oak to the palate, and as a unique part of the finish, spearmint, which isn't to be found in other expressions.

I'm no fan of Diageo. They seem (perhaps rightfully so in their minds) more interested in the bottom line than making sure everything they put out is a quality product. I'm not a fan of their passing on the new tariffs to the consumer almost instantly after the new year. I'm not a fan that this is now $110 in Texas. But damn if this isn't good whisky, and damn it all if I won't shell out the money for it. Curse you Diageo and your soulless milking of your loyal consumers. You know we'll pay...

Peaty and meaty smell. Not too harsh. Fresh notes of citrus, green apple and freshly cut grass linger behind the smoke. 
The peat is dominant in the taste, but soon you are welcomed by an oily and fruity taste of apples, pear, and vanilla. Very full and fruity. 
Caramel and a subtle oakiness dominate the finish
Very peaty and incredibly smooth. My favorite Islay
A full barbecue (brine, a dead cow and tobacco ash) topped out with sea salt made by roof layers turning over the barbecue meat with hands dipped in black tar.

Super smooth, doesn’t come at you too fast, but when it does, so much smoke, spice, meat, peat it’s crazy. But then after a few sips you start to realize there’s more to it and find some sweetness. Like if you barbecued a steak and then the some roasted cherries on top.

When you initially embark into the odyssey of this liquid gold masterpiece, you feel as if you’re sitting at a backyard barbecue. Not like you’re just smelling the barbecue down the street as you walk your dogs by, but you are IN the barbecue. The sweet, the smoke, the meat, the burn. You are on the grill beside the porterhouse inhaling the fumes of the charcoal flames and that glorious red meat. Then after the smoke of the grill, just for a fleeting instance, you’re all gathered around the pool eating fresh homemade vanilla ice cream. It’s just a microcosm of a moment: solely so the sweetness doesn’t burst through the pallet as the forerunner of flavor; that’s alright, just a suggestion of sweetness is more than enough. After sweetness foolishly thought it had a chance, we’re back to the town of flavor with the taste of either of these three: 1.) a freshly burned, liquified Sharpie, 2.) a freshly felled white oak tree on a warm summer’s eve, or 3.) a fresh mouthful of smoldered ashes, most likely from an incinerated cigar factory. The interpretation, and choice, are up to the individual experience. I’m not here to judge, friends. 

Whichever flavor you experience, you experience it not only from your oral cavity, but furthermore via your nose, eyes, and ears. It’s due to the actuality this scotch never lets up from commencement to culmination. Even hours after you acquire that first memorable, incandescent sip you can sense it making its voyage down to your toes. And, really, what more could you ever aspire for?

This is my special scotch to drink - the “Oh, you just got married? That’s not special enough to drink my Lagavulin” scotch. 

Five stars.

The king of the smoky Islay malts. Like drinking an ashtray. Cigar smoke on the nose, cigar smoke and caramelized toffee flavors, and an immensely warming finish. You are either in the mood for this, or you aren't. No two ways about it.
Peated, smoky, saltyness, seaweed. Very nice whisky!
Is there anything else to say about Lagavulin 16 that has not been said by Nick Offerman? Yeah, No.

Tasted neat.

On the nose the first note I get is bacon, bacon flavored dog treats to be precise. Some charred wood, burnt rubber, leather, camp fire by the beach. Amazing.

On the palate I get smoke meats, sweet peat (not as medicinal as Ardbeg/Laphroaig) cigar ash/tobacco, BBQ chips, it warms your chest and comes back up with some crushed pepper.

Finish is long with more delicious BBQ smoked meats notes. Fantastic scotch.
Is there a better Islay (or Scotch) whisky in the world? I think not, and Ron Swanson would have to agree. You might believe it was mixed with a Speyside because it is so smooth and mild mannered.
The nectar of the Gods.  When drinking, I visualize myself standing on a cliff facing the North Sea!

Nose : smoke, peat, iodine, seawater, well balanced an round.
Taste : smokey, sweat barbecue sauce, slight pepper
Finish : peppery, warm, slightly bitter, dryness in the end
So nice. Smooth and clean and Smokey. One of my all time favourites.
